sentences.chinese: 魏公子無忌者，魏昭王子少子而魏安釐王異母弟也。
sentences.literal: Lord Xinling of Wei, whose courtesy name was Wuji, was the youngest son of King Zhao of Wei and the half-brother of King Anli of Wei.

sentences.chinese: 昭王薨，安釐王即位，封公子為信陵君。
sentences.literal: When King Zhao died and King Anli ascended the throne, he enfeoffed the prince as Lord Xinling.
The King of Wei and the prince were greatly troubled by this.

sentences.chinese: 公子為人仁而下士，士無賢不肖皆謙而禮交之，不敢以其富貴驕士。
sentences.literal: The prince was benevolent by nature and deferential to scholars. Regardless of whether they were worthy or unworthy, he treated all scholars with humility and courtesy, never allowing his wealth and nobility to make him arrogant toward them.

sentences.chinese: 士以此方數千里爭往歸之，致食客三千人。
sentences.literal: Because of this, scholars from regions several thousand li around vied with one another to come and serve him, swelling his retainers to three thousand men.

sentences.chinese: 當是時，諸侯以公子賢，多客，不敢加兵謀魏十餘年。
sentences.literal: At this time, the feudal lords considered the prince worthy and well-attended by retainers, so they did not dare attack or plot against Wei for more than ten years.
The King of Wei set down his game pieces and wished to summon his ministers for consultation.
They resumed their game as before.
The king was fearful, his mind not on the game.

sentences.chinese: 公子聞之，往請，欲厚遺之。
sentences.literal: The prince heard of him and went to invite him, wishing to bestow generous gifts upon him.

sentences.chinese: 公子於是乃置酒大會賓客。
sentences.literal: Thereupon the prince prepared wine and held a great gathering of his retainers.

sentences.chinese: 坐定，公子從車騎，虛左，自迎夷門侯生。
sentences.literal: When all were seated, the prince took his chariot and retinue, leaving the honored left seat empty, and personally went to welcome Master Hou of the Yi Gate.
The prince held the reins with even greater deference.

sentences.chinese: 公子引車入市，侯生下見其客朱亥，俾倪故久立，與其客語，微察公子。
sentences.literal: The prince drove his chariot into the market. Master Hou got down to see his friend Zhu Hai, deliberately standing for a long time while talking with his friend, carefully observing the prince's demeanor.
All the people in the market watched the prince holding the reins.
